mESFMx-y2.memHandModelNotes:
****Species found in expansion joints of bridges, intersect rivers with roads and select those pixels at interesect in addition to the PMU pixels. Amy Silvano 16jun05.   'M. Leibii occur at elevations of 300-780m in PA, 750m in VA, 1125m in Kentucky, and 240-675m in GA' (Troy & Jennings 1997). Because of variable elevation throughout the Southeast just applied minimum elevation parameter. Amy Silvano 31jan06

Exterior water buffer was 0 meters, i.e. would restrict to water only. Edited to include unlimited exterior water buffer 9999. Hand model notes using rivers/streams intersecting with roads. I think this is just a small portion of the range and would require too much work for little small additions to habitat. Eliminated hand modeling. MJR 17 October 2007.

Baker, Rollin H. 1983. Michigan mammals. Michigan State University Press. 642 pp.

habitat_description:
The Eastern Small-footed Myotis (Myotis leibii) is a small, uncommon bat only found in eastern deciduous and coniferous forests (Smithsonian 2013).  It does not make long distance migrations.

Habitat is mostly hilly or mountainous areas, in or near deciduous or evergreen forest, sometimes in open farmland (NatureServe 2005). 

Summer roost sites have been found in crevices of rock outcrops and boulders, shallow caves, holes and crevices in earthen banks, hollow trees, undersides of loose bark, and barns (Lee et al. 1982; Webster et al. 1985; Whitaker and Hamilton 1998).  Unpublished data from the Kentucky Heritage Program indicate that summer roosts include caves, coal mines, buildings, and bridges over rivers (in expansion joints).  In the southern Appalachians, roosts have also been found in hemlock forest (Webster et al. 1985).  Tuttle (1964) reported two individuals found in April in Tennessee under a large flat rock at the edge of a quarry surrounded by woods and cow pastures” (NatureServe 2013). 

The only known winter roosts are in caves and mines (Best and Jennings 1997).

They forage over small ponds & streams; along cliffs and ledges; and in wooded areas (Choate et al. 1994, NatureServe 2005).  – Regional habitat notes edited by N. Tarr, 6December2013.
